name: Chuck's Molasses French Toast
description: The molasses in the batter gives this version of the classic breakfast food a caramel coating that is quite delicious. This one also proves to be a great way to use up the left over Challah from Shabbat on a Saturday morning.
recipeIngredient: 1 pinch ground cinnamon, or more to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Beat together the eggs, molasses, cream, vanilla, ginger, and cinnamon in a bowl until smooth. Dip the challah slices in the batter until coated on all sides.

Melt half of the butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Place half of the challah slices into the pan, and cook until golden brown on each side, about 3 minutes per side. Repeat with remaining butter and challah slices.

review.reviewBody: I would give this 5 stars with a lot more spices. Although it has molasses we still needed nutmeg and more cinnamon with some clove. YUM! Also we used Almond milk instead of heavy cream. Our new favorite french toast recipe for sure.
The flavoring of the molasses is subtle and is quite delicious.  I sprinkled in a lot more cinnamon than the recipe called for.

I made several adjustments to the recipe and the result was what I call the perfect french toast.  I used 2 tbsp of molasses.  I whisked in about 3 tbsp of flour and 2 tbsp of sugar into the egg/milk mixture.  I did not have cream so I used milk and still got good results.  I also put in a small pinch of salt.  I read that putting flour into the milk mixture will help the bread to get crispier and it did!!   Also, use lots of butter in your pan which helps the bread to get a crispier coating.  The result is a french toast with a nice crispy brown outside and the inside had a nice combination of a bread / custard-like texture.  I do not like french toast that has a heavy custard texture on the inside!!  The flavor has a nice balance of sweet and somewhat savory with the ginger/salt combination.  Oh and I also added a dash of nutmeg as I do to most things that I bake.

Even though I healthied this up by using whole wheat bread and milk in place of the cream I though this was fantastic.  I was a little heavier with my spices but it's the molasses that really makes this dish.  It adds such depth.  Great recipe.

This recipe is so good!  I made it at a family camp out with the boy scouts.  I whipped up the custard the night before at home and put it in the cooler.  All we had was Shop n Save white bread but it was oh so tasty and it had rave reviews from the scouts and leaders!  Will definitely be making this again!

Excellent!  I did choose to add extra ginger and cinnamon like other reviewers.  And I only had thick butt ends of cinnamon raisin bread, which I believe made it even better! Mmm. This recipe is definitely worth a bookmark!

HUGE hit with all of us. We absolutely loved this. I don't keep challah bread on hand so I used the whole wheat I had at home. Also, because I did not have heavy cream, I used fat free evaporated milk because it's good at mimicking the thickness and richness of cream. I doubled this recipe (we're big on french toast in this house--my husband and kids can eat almost a whole loaf in one sitting) and I was a little more liberal with the spices. I served this with my homemade maple-vanilla syrup and we all just loved this french toast. This might be my new go-to recipe to make french toast from now on. NOTE: I did not use the butter to cook the french toast. I used my huge countertop grill which is VERY non-stick, so the butter was unnecessary. We spread it on the hot french toast after. ;)

This was tasty for me (I love dark molasses). The bf added European butter and Maple Syrup. He is not a fan of molasses.

I did not use Challah bread (I do not keep that "in stock" and this was a whim). I used plain old white bread. 

I am lacto-intolerant and he drank all of his 2% milk other day so I subbed Silk Soy Milk. 

Next time I think I would use 2 tbls and 2 tsp of molasses. Will try this again but have to find a way to make the bf also happy.
The color and subtle flavor added by the molasses was very good.
loved it a great way to spice up your everyday french toast with a more bold taste.
Eh, it was okay. I thought the molasses was a bit much. It was nice to try a different variation of French toast.
Delicious change up to a standard recipe!  Didn't have ginger on hand but otherwise followed the recipe.  Molasses added a subtle flavor!
Excellent! The molasses really adds a great flavour.
So good.  I used Pumpkin Challah bread and it really made it more perfect!
Nice flavoring from the typical french toast.  I like a bit more ginger and cinnamon
perfect!!! used vanilla rice milk as i didn't have any heavy cream and I forgot the ginger. deeelishioussss

Just made this recipe with "Cinnamon Cream Syrup" recipe from this site. It was DELICIOUS! Only thing I did differently was add a little salt to the egg mixture and I used French Bread (from "French Bread" recipe from this site, also an excellent recipe)

Ehhh...it's OK.  The molasses flavor was pretty strong.  I added a little extra ginger and cinnamon and also added some nutmeg, but none of that really came through over the molasses.  Not terrible, but I don't think I'll make this one again.
EXCELLENT.  Used approximately half a tsp of cinnamon + a pinch more, and added chopped pecans on top of each slice.  The flavor of the pecans intensified due to the cooking.  Incredibly good.
Fantastic! I love the depth the molasses adds. Used 1 tsp. cinnamon + tad of sugar.
as is, this was just so-so for us. i think next time we'll try the other reviewers suggestions and increase the spices.

I used wheat bread and regular milk, so i was not thrilled about this recipe... although my changes probably have everything to do with it. Will definitely make again, next time when i have challah on hand
This is a nice change from regular French toast.  If you like gingerbread you probably will like this recipe.

Have made this several times almost as written - used whole graim wheat bread and a few times forgot the cinnamon.  It is delicious anytime of day.... ive even had this for dessert.  I drizzled organic ginger syrup that I happened to have In my pantry on top with whipped cream over that.

Yum...the texture in these is great! All caramelized and yummy. Don't be afraid to let these get really well done-that's how they're best.  I have discovered though that i am really not a fan of molasses, no matter how hard i try. :) I think i'll leave it out next time... Oh, and i only used 2 T of molasses and added a bit more than a pinch of cinnamon sugar.
I love French Toast and molasses....but just wasn't crazy about this recipe.  I did dust with powdered sugar and thought that helped....

We liked this rather subtle variation. I left out the sugar - no need when you are going to use syrup anyway. I didn't get much molasses flavor so may add more next time. We embellished with fresh raspberries. yum.

This was wonderul, thank you for the recipe.  I didn't have any Challah bread and used sprouted bread (Ezekiel bread).  The batter only made enouh to cover 8 slices of bread so I will double it next time.
Great recipe.  I substituted ground nutmeg for the ginger.
This recipe was fantastic. I made it for brunch. My whole family loved them.

I followed the recipe and found it to be too sweet for us. I would suggest using less molasses - and ensure you use light not dark. 

Cheers, and thanks for sharing
Made it  at least twice. Five stars!

I made several adjustments to the recipe and the result was what I call the perfect french toast.  I used 2 tbsp of molasses.  I whisked in about 3 tbsp of flour and 2 tbsp of sugar into the egg/milk mixture.  I did not have cream so I used milk and still got good results.  I also put in a small pinch of salt.  I read that putting flour into the milk mixture will help the bread to get crispier and it did!!   Also, use lots of butter in your pan which helps the bread to get a crispier coating.  The result is a french toast with a nice crispy brown outside and the inside had a nice combination of a bread / custard-like texture.  I do not like french toast that has a heavy custard texture on the inside!!  The flavor has a nice balance of sweet and somewhat savory with the ginger/salt combination.  Oh and I also added a dash of nutmeg as I do to most things that I bake.

This is a great bass recipe I used brioche bread I added gingerbread spices, so to add with the molasses I had Ginger clove nutmeg cinnamon a little bit of allspice so it had a gingerbread flavor French toast it was amazing everyone loved it it was the hit of Christmas morning
I followed the recipe exactly other then all I had was some white bread.  My wife loved it but I thought it was lacking a wow factor.  Will make it again since she like it.

I have used Brioche, Texas toast, and cinnamon swirl bread. I don't bother with heavy cream; I have used unsweetened vanilla almond milk, evaporated milk, skim milk,  and there is a little difference but not much. My favorite bread is the cinnamon swirl!
